habitat: Widely distributed and common east of the Rocky Mountains wherever conifers occur naturally.
shortDescription: An inedible bolete (but not poisonous) with slightly to distinctly pink pores on the underside of the bun-shaped brown cap, a dark net on the thick stem, and a very bitter taste.
benefitsOrToxicity: In some countries, used as a substitute for pepper.

identification.cap: 5–13 cm; convex, becoming broadly convex or nearly flat; dry; bald and softly leathery; unpolished; sometimes cracked; brown, fading to tan.
identification.stem: 4–10 cm long; 1.5–4 cm thick; club-shaped; whitish to pale brownish above; pale brown to tan elsewhere; strongly reticulate with wide-meshed brown net at least on upper third; basal mycelium white.
identification.flesh: Thick; soft; white; unchanging when sliced.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores 10–16 × 3–4 µm; narrowly fusiform to subfusiform; smooth; hyaline to yellowish in KOH. Hymenial cystidia 30–40 × 8–10 µm; fusiform; smooth; thin-walled; hyaline in KOH; sometimes with golden inclusion. Pileipellis a tangled cutis of cylindric elements 5–7.5 µm wide; golden yellow in KOH; terminal cells erect, rounded to subacute.

note: Type species of Tylopilus; first described as Boletus felleus by Bulliard in 1788; transferred to Tylopilus by Karsten in 1881.
